articles.headline: This Boutique Bike Shop Shows How Trump’s Tariffs Can Hit the Little Guy
articles.snippet: It’s hard for a small, China-dependent company to reorient its supply chain on a dime.
articles.abstract: It’s hard for a small, China-dependent company to reorient its supply chain on a dime.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shane Cusick started his small business, Pello, in 2014 with the goal of making lightweight bikes for children. His experience over the past year is a case study in how a trade war can disrupt a fledgling enterprise.

articles.headline: The Fiat-Renault Merger: Pitfalls and Potential Profits
articles.snippet: If all goes well, the carmakers could have the financial and industrial brawn to dominate. But the history of auto mega-mergers is not encouraging.
articles.abstract: If all goes well, the carmakers could have the financial and industrial brawn to dominate. But the history of auto mega-mergers is not encouraging.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles is playing up its proposed merger with Renault, unveiled on Monday, as a chance to create a European-American carmaker with the financial and industrial brawn to survive a turbulent age.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing, Neal E. Boudette and Ben Dooley

articles.headline: Mueller Delivered a Message. Washington Couldn’t Agree on What It Was.
articles.snippet: As he stepped down from his role as special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III refused to exonerate President Trump but also avoided being declarative enough to change many minds.
articles.abstract: As he stepped down from his role as special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III refused to exonerate President Trump but also avoided being declarative enough to change many minds.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At long last, the sphinx of Washington spoke on Wednesday, and here is what President Trump heard: “Case closed.” Here is what the president’s adversaries heard: “Time to impeach.”

articles.headline: Michael Wolff Talks ‘Siege,’ Trump, Journalism and His Definition of Truth
articles.snippet: “I’m a New York guy,” the author says. “Trump is a New York guy. In the end, we know a lot of the same people.”
articles.abstract: “I’m a New York guy,” the author says. “Trump is a New York guy. In the end, we know a lot of the same people.”
articles.lead_paragraph: “Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House,” Michael Wolff’s account of President Trump’s early tenure, sold more than four million copies, spawned a TV deal, prompted the president to threaten legal action and led to the ouster of Stephen K. Bannon from the White House and Breitbart News.

articles.headline: The Bond Market Is Trying to Tell Us Something (Worry)
articles.snippet: Bond yields, the yield curve, inflation expectations, Fed-rate predictions. The bond market might seem indecipherable, but it’s full of important clues about the economy.
articles.abstract: Bond yields, the yield curve, inflation expectations, Fed-rate predictions. The bond market might seem indecipherable, but it’s full of important clues about the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Let’s face it: Bonds are boring. Usually, stock markets are the source of hyperventilation and headlines.
articles.byline: By Stephen Grocer and Matt Phillips

articles.headline: In Israel’s New Election Campaign, Right Battles Right
articles.snippet: The fight between the secular right and the religious right thwarted Benjamin Netanyahu’s attempt to form a government and has eclipsed the old left-right divide.
articles.abstract: The fight between the secular right and the religious right thwarted Benjamin Netanyahu’s attempt to form a government and has eclipsed the old left-right divide.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — After the spectacular collapse of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s attempt to build a coalition threw Israel into an unprecedented do-over election, Israeli public attention on Thursday was glued to two politicians.

articles.headline: Deceased G.O.P. Strategist’s Hard Drives Reveal New Details on the Census Citizenship Question
articles.snippet: Weeks before the Supreme Court rules on the legality of the citizenship question, evidence filed in court could further erode the Trump administration’s rationale for the question.
articles.abstract: Weeks before the Supreme Court rules on the legality of the citizenship question, evidence filed in court could further erode the Trump administration’s rationale for the question.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thomas B. Hofeller achieved near-mythic status in the Republican Party as the Michelangelo of gerrymandering, the architect of partisan political maps that cemented the party’s dominance across the country.

articles.headline: Let’s Not Upset the President: The White House Tells the Navy to Hide the U.S.S. McCain
articles.snippet: The request was an effort to keep Mr. McCain’s name out of photographs while Mr. Trump was at a naval base in Japan.
articles.abstract: The request was an effort to keep Mr. McCain’s name out of photographs while Mr. Trump was at a naval base in Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House’s directive to hide a Navy destroyer named after Senator John McCain during President Trump’s recent visit to a naval base in Japan was driven, administration officials said on Thursday, by a fear of bad visuals — the name of the president’s nemesis clearly visible in photographs of him.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Eileen Sullivan

articles.headline: Victory for Fathers in a Parental Leave Case That Could Be a Harbinger
articles.snippet: As more employers offer paid time off after childbirth, a class-action suit has yielded a settlement in which JPMorgan has pledged equal treatment for men and women.
articles.abstract: As more employers offer paid time off after childbirth, a class-action suit has yielded a settlement in which JPMorgan has pledged equal treatment for men and women.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, scholars, activists and mothers have criticized policies that place the burden of child-rearing overwhelmingly on women. Increasingly, fathers are joining the criticism of these policies — and asserting their legal rights to challenge them.
